Award.AwardTitle: Galectins of the eastern oyster (C. virginica) and softshell clam (M. arenaria) as determinants for host preference and pathogenicity of sympatric Perkinsus parasite species
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oysters and clams constitute not only shellfishery resources of high commercial value, but also very important components of the estuarine and coastal environment in the USA Therefore, infectious diseases in these bivalve species have serious impacts in both the shellfisheries industry and health of the environment. Among the several diseases that affect shellfish in the USA, Perkinsus (Dermo) parasites have caused severe mortalities in natural and farmed oyster populations and no effective preventive or therapeutic solutions have been developed so far. For most shellfish diseases, little is known about the mechanisms of parasite specificity for the host, infection, and transmission. During prior studies the investigators discovered that Perkinsus parasites subvert a host defense protein (galectin) to gain entry in the oyster cells and cause disease. Now they will elucidate how the eastern oyster and softshell clam galectins determine the host specificity of the different Perkinsus species, how they modulate the survival of the parasite in oyster and clams, and how they negatively affect the functions of the immune cells. This information will be critical to understand how and why the different Perkinsus species are more or less pathogenic for certain shellfish species. This fundamental knowledge will enable the development of innovative methods to prevent infections, pathogenic effects of the parasites, and their transmission to healthy shellfish populations. Educational and training aspects will be actively pursued specifically incorporating underrepresented minorities and women. The fundamental knowledge obtained will contribute new insight into parasitic disease in animals of agricultural interest and man.

In contrast with Perkinsus marinus that is highly pathogenic for eastern oysters, the sympatric P. chesapeaki, initially isolated from the softshell clam Mya arenaria, can also be present in oysters but there is little evidence of pathogenicity. Prior studies revealed in the eastern oyster two opsonic galectins that strongly recognize P. marinus, but weakly recognize P. chesapeaki; the clam expresses a galectin of distinct specificity. This led to the hypothesis that host preference and pathogenicity of Perkinsus species is directly related to galectin-mediated host entry, and ability to modulate hemocyte function and expression of galectins upon infection. This hypothesis will be tested by using molecular, genetic, biochemical, structural and cell biology approaches to elucidate: (a) the structural basis for differential recognition of Perkinsus spp by the oyster and clam galectins; (b) the effects of galectin-mediated differential recognition of Perkinsus spp on opsonization, phagocytosis, and intrahemocytic parasite survival; and (c) the mechanisms mediated by galectin binding to parasite and hemocyte surface receptors and co-receptors and the modulation of signaling pathways that regulate hemocyte function(s). Thus, the proposed activity will be highly transformative of the long-held concept that parasite mimicry is a strategy to avoid recognition by the host, while the proposed model would reveal acquisition of glycomimicry by the parasite aimed not only at promoting host recognition for entry and pathogenicity, but with necessary specificity to determine host preference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Eastern oysters and softshell clams are very important bivalve species along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of North America not only from the commercial fisheries aspect, but to ecosystem integrity as they are filter-feeders and maintain the water quality. Both species, however, can be infected by protozoan parasites (Perkinsus species), with distinct outcomes. For example, Perkinsus marinus causes “Dermo” disease in the eastern oyster, and is responsible for the catastrophic decline of natural and farmed oyster populations in the Chesapeake Bay. In contrast, the parasite P. chesapeaki, initially isolated from the softshell clam (Mya arenaria), can also be present in oysters but there is little evidence of pathogenicity. Thus, the problem of host preference and pathogenicity of Perkinsus species for Chesapeake Bay shellfish remains to be fully understood.

Intellectual merit

Shellfish lack the antibodies that are typical of immune systems of vertebrates. Instead, recognition of microbial pathogens is achieved, at least in part, by carbohydrate-binding proteins named lectins, of which several types have been identified. In the oyster we have identified two lectins of the galectin type (which we named CvGal1 and CvGal2) that bind to the parasite P. marinus, and discovered that while they function in immune defense and feeding, they are “hijacked” by this parasite to gain entry into the host phagocytic cells. Most interestingly, we discovered that the oyster galectins do not recognize P. chesapeaki.  In the softshell clam we identified a galectin (MaGal1) which recognizes both P. marinus and P. chesapeaki, suggesting that the differential recognition of Perkinsus species by the oyster and clam galectins may be responsible for the differential pathogenicity of Perkinsus for their hosts.

The major goal of the project was to investigate in detail the carbohydrate specificity of the clam lectins and compare them to the oyster lectins to identify the potential structural basis for their distinct recognition properties for Perkinsus parasites. We also investigated the carbohydrates present on the surface of P. marinus and P. chesapeaki, to explain their differential recognition by the host lectins. Finally, with this information we planned functional studies to examine the role(s) of these lectins in interactions between the parasites and the host phagocytic cells and the mechanisms that may be activated to enable an effective defense response. The experimental plan included molecular, genomic, biochemical, biophysical, structural and cell biology experimental approaches, and we developed multiple tools (molecular probes, transcript databases, antisera) that enabled detailed studies on these lectins. Results revealed that the galectin MaGal1 from the softshell clam has carbohydrate specificity and recognition properties for Perkinsus species different from the oyster galectins. Analysis of the carbohydrates present on the surface of P. marinus and P. chesapeaki also revealed differences that suggest their differential recognition by galectins. A rigorous analysis of the clam lectin repertoire using the databases we developed resulted in the identification of a diverse number of lectin families, including R-, C-, and F-type lectins which are known as involved in innate immunity of shellfish. Among these lectins, we carried out detailed studies on the R-type lectin MaRTL1, which we identified as a galactosyl-binding lectin and therefore, likely to also recognize Perkinsus species. Taken together, these results may contribute to explain distinct host recognition as well as infectivity or pathogenicity of these parasites for these two shellfish species. The results of this project have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals and book chapters, and at least two additional manuscripts are in preparation for publication in the near future.

Given the regional commercial and ecological relevance of softshell clams and eastern oysters in Chesapeake Bay, the new knowledge that this project provided is highly significant in that it will contribute to develop novel intervention strategies (such as the synthesis of inhibitors of shellfish lectins that will prevent or at least reduce parasite infection) to restore natural and farmed shellfish populations and environmental quality of the coastal estuaries in the US.

Broader impacts

This study provided novel information not only about the roles of the lectins from shellfish in their differential susceptibility to Perkinsus parasites, but also represents a useful model system that provides fundamental knowledge about the role(s) of protein-carbohydrate interactions in innate defense mechanisms against infectious disease in vertebrates, including humans.

Equally important, we used the clam/oyster-Perkinsus model system for educational and training purposes. This system enables classroom integration of fundamental scientific principles related to: (a) ecosystem health of Chesapeake Bay and other estuaries along the eastern coast of US, and (b) immune recognition mechanisms and host-parasite biology. In addition to post-doctoral associates and junior faculty, several undergraduate and high school students, mostly from underrepresented minorities from the Baltimore/Washington area, participated throughout the funding period both as interns at the bench and in the classroom, and some shared co-authorship in conference presentations, peer-reviewed papers, and book chapters.
